pull_request.title: Add support for bounds
pull_request.body:
## Description
The first step of adding the attribute effectively is implementing support for lower and upper bounds for variables and parameters. The second step would involve passing the domain constraints directly to the solver so that solvers can exploit the properties of those types of constraints.
Issue link (if applicable):
https://github.com/cvxpy/cvxpy/issues/1106

## Type of change
- [x] New feature (backwards compatible)
- [ ] New feature (breaking API changes)
- [ ] Bug fix
- [ ] Other (Documentation, CI, ...)

## [Contribution checklist](https://www.cvxpy.org/contributing/index.html#contribution-checklist)
- [ ] Add our license to new files.
- [ ] Check that your code adheres to our coding style.
- [x] Write unittests.
- [x] Run the unittests and check that they’re passing.
- [ ] Run the benchmarks to make sure your change doesn’t introduce a regression.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -529,4 +529,46 @@ def bounds(self, value):
             raise ValueError("Invalid bounds: some upper bounds are less "
                              "than corresponding lower bounds.")
 
+        if is_lower_scalar and is_upper_scalar:
+            if (lower_bounds == -np.inf
+                    and upper_bounds == -np.inf):
+                raise ValueError("-np.inf is not feasible as lower "
+                                 "and upper bound.")
+            if (lower_bounds == np.inf
+                    and upper_bounds == np.inf):
+                raise ValueError("np.inf is not feasible as lower "
+                                 "and upper bound.")
+            if (lower_bounds == np.nan
+                    or upper_bounds == np.nan):
comment.body: `np.nan == np.nan` always evaluates to `False`. You have to use `np.isnan`

issue.title: Add support for bounds
issue.body:
## Description
The first step of adding the attribute effectively is implementing support for lower and upper bounds for variables and parameters. The second step would involve passing the domain constraints directly to the solver so that solvers can exploit the properties of those types of constraints.
Issue link (if applicable):
https://github.com/cvxpy/cvxpy/issues/1106

## Type of change
- [x] New feature (backwards compatible)
- [ ] New feature (breaking API changes)
- [ ] Bug fix
- [ ] Other (Documentation, CI, ...)

## [Contribution checklist](https://www.cvxpy.org/contributing/index.html#contribution-checklist)
- [ ] Add our license to new files.
- [ ] Check that your code adheres to our coding style.
- [x] Write unittests.
- [x] Run the unittests and check that they’re passing.

comment.body: For now, there is no support for something like `Variable((2,), bounds=[np.array([1]), np.array([2])])`. Should this case be considered the same as `Variable((2,), bounds=[1, 2])` ? Since `np.array` support is currently for variables and parameters with dimension >=2

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -483,3 +485,48 @@ def is_dpp(self, context: str = 'dcp') -> bool:
 
     def atoms(self) -> list[Atom]:
         return []
+
+    @property
+    def bounds(self):
+        return self._bounds
+
+    @bounds.setter
+    def bounds(self, value):
+        # In case for a constant or no bounds
+        if value is None:
+            self._bounds = None
+            return
+
+        # Check that bounds is a list of two items
+        if not isinstance(value, list) or len(value) != 2:
+            raise ValueError("Bounds should be a list of two items.")
+
+        lower_bounds, upper_bounds = value
+
+        # Check if lower and upper bounds are always passed together
+        if (lower_bounds is None and upper_bounds is not None):
+            raise ValueError("If upper bounds are passed, lower bounds should also be passed.")
+        if (lower_bounds is not None and upper_bounds is None):
+            raise ValueError("If lower bounds are passed, upper bounds should also be passed.")
+
+        # Check that bounds contains two scalars or two arrays with matching shapes.
+        is_lower_scalar = np.isscalar(lower_bounds)
+        is_upper_scalar = np.isscalar(upper_bounds)
+        is_lower_array = isinstance(lower_bounds, np.ndarray)
+        is_upper_array = isinstance(upper_bounds, np.ndarray)
+        if not((is_lower_scalar and is_upper_scalar) or
+               (is_lower_scalar and is_upper_array
+                and upper_bounds.shape == self.shape) or
+               (is_upper_scalar and is_lower_array
+                and lower_bounds.shape == self.shape) or
+               (is_lower_array and is_upper_array
+                and lower_bounds.shape == self.shape
+                and upper_bounds.shape == self.shape)):
+            raise ValueError("Bounds should contain scalars and/or arrays with the same dimensions")
+
+        # Check that upper_bound >= lower_bound
+        if np.any(upper_bounds < lower_bounds):
comment.body: Thanks! I added validations for the situation if `np.inf` and `-np.inf` is encountered in lower and upper bounds at the same position/component of the variable. Also added validations if `np.nan` occurs in lower and/or upper bound (I marked those situation as invalid and give back an error). I think the situation for `np.inf` in lower bound (and same logic `-np.inf` in upper) should be handled by now since if `np.inf` in lower and `np.inf` in upper, we get the Value error from the latest commit + if the user passes something else than `np.inf` in upper it must be considered smaller compared to `np.inf` (and the condition `upper_bounds >= lower_bounds` should trigger?)

issue.title: Update swig autogenerated files to swig 4.1.1
issue.body:
## Description
Swig 4.0.2 is very old and, critically for me, contains [this](https://github.com/swig/swig/issues/1985) bug which causes a memory leak (and crashes the program if LeakSan is attached). In this PR I simply regenerated the files using `rebuild_cvxcore.sh` with swig 4.1.1 installed (I also removed the argument `-py3` from `rebuild_cvxcore.sh` since swig claims is now deprecated and has no use).

## Type of change
- [ ] New feature (backwards compatible)
- [ ] New feature (breaking API changes)
- [x] Bug fix
- [x] Other (Documentation, CI, ...)

## [Contribution checklist](https://www.cvxpy.org/contributing/index.html#contribution-checklist)
- [ ] Add our license to new files.
- [ ] Check that your code adheres to our coding style.
- [ ] Write unittests.
- [ ] Run the unittests and check that they’re passing.
- [ ] Run the benchmarks to make sure your change doesn’t introduce a regression.

issue.title: Cannot access to variable.value
issue.body:
Hello everyone ! 
**Description**
I run into an error trying to access a variable value after solving an optimisation problem with linear matrix inequalities :

![LMI_problem](https://github.com/cvxpy/cvxpy/assets/73585075/56124e71-fb5b-4fee-9ef0-70f6d76e9827)

the matrix $T>0$ here is diagonal and is a decision variable
The problem status is okay and the value of the objective I am trying to minimize (here the value of L) is the correct one on a dummy example.

Now when I want to access $M_l (L^2, W)$ I have the following error : 

![bug_cvxpy](https://github.com/cvxpy/cvxpy/assets/73585075/0b05205e-aea5-42e3-a700-13551e1a1c8f)

It seems to be caused by one part of the matrix which is stored as a sparse variable : 

![console](https://github.com/cvxpy/cvxpy/assets/73585075/8711f36a-c291-4a78-84e6-a7edf2944f83)

Thie variable which seems to be stored in a sparse fashion is a subpart of the matrix $T$, I think.


**To reproduce**
As it is part of a research paper implementation a minimal code takes a little time to write but if it helps I'll send one.

**Version**
 - CVXPY Version: 1.2.1

Thank you for your help !

comment.body: it looks like you are combining numpy or some such library with cvxpy. This is not supported and leads to errors such as you are seeing. Specifically you cannot ever apply numpy function to cvxpy objects.

As it is part of a research paper implementation a minimal code takes a little time to write but if it helps I'll send one.

**Version**
 - CVXPY Version: 1.2.1

Thank you for your help !

issue.title: Why is this convex expression not DCP?
issue.body:
I'm trying to minimize the function $(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2$ which is convex, where $x$ is a the optimization variable, a vector, and $\Sigma$ is a covariance matrix. The expression $(x^T \Sigma x)^2$ is DCP and can be optimized, but the expression $(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2$ is not DCP. I don't understand why this is, because $x^T \Sigma x$ resolves down to a scalar, so essentially we have $(scalar - 1)^2=scaler$ which I believe is still convex.

If we expand the brackets in the expression $(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2$, let $u=x^T\Sigma x$, then we have

$$
(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2 = (u - 1)^2 = (u - 1)(u - 1) = u^2 - 2u + 1
$$

Again, the expression $u^2 - 2u + 1$ is not DCP, but the expression $u^2 + 2u + 1$ is DCP (note the sign change on the $2u$). Why is this the case and is there a way to resolve it? Thank you

comment.body:
Thanks for explaining it to me. I failed to see that $x^T \Sigma x$ is like having $x^2$, and so $(x^T\Sigma x - 1)^2$ is like having $(x^2-1)^2$ which of course isn't convex.
As for the argument about $f(x)$ resolving to a scalar, that also makes sense.

issue.title: Why is this convex expression not DCP?
issue.body:
I'm trying to minimize the function $(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2$ which is convex, where $x$ is a the optimization variable, a vector, and $\Sigma$ is a covariance matrix. The expression $(x^T \Sigma x)^2$ is DCP and can be optimized, but the expression $(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2$ is not DCP. I don't understand why this is, because $x^T \Sigma x$ resolves down to a scalar, so essentially we have $(scalar - 1)^2=scaler$ which I believe is still convex.

If we expand the brackets in the expression $(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2$, let $u=x^T\Sigma x$, then we have

$$
(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2 = (u - 1)^2 = (u - 1)(u - 1) = u^2 - 2u + 1
$$

Again, the expression $u^2 - 2u + 1$ is not DCP, but the expression $u^2 + 2u + 1$ is DCP (note the sign change on the $2u$). Why is this the case and is there a way to resolve it? Thank you

comment.body:
Your not function is not convex to begin with, even in $1$ dimension, just plot the graph of $(x^2-1)^2$ to see the problem.

The "other" function, $(x^T\Sigma x+1)^2$ is convex.

issue.title: `cvxpy` fails to install on Python 3.12
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Running `pip install cvxpy` fails when using Python 3.12 **To Reproduce** ``` conda create -n py312-cvxpy python=3.12 conda activate py312-cvxpy pip install cvxpy ``` **Output** **Version** - OS: macOS - CVXPY Version: latest **Additional context** - I checked and it works fine using Python 3.11 - I'm using an M1 mac.

comment.body:
SCS compilation on Python 3.12 is work in progress, there's a PR open (https://github.com/bodono/scs-python/pull/70). If you are on mac or linux this should work
```
pip install git+https://github.com/enzbus/scs-python
pip install cvxpy
```

issue.title: Why is this convex expression not DCP?
issue.body:
I'm trying to minimize the function $(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2$ which is convex, where $x$ is a the optimization variable, a vector, and $\Sigma$ is a covariance matrix. The expression $(x^T \Sigma x)^2$ is DCP and can be optimized, but the expression $(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2$ is not DCP. I don't understand why this is, because $x^T \Sigma x$ resolves down to a scalar, so essentially we have $(scalar - 1)^2=scaler$ which I believe is still convex.

If we expand the brackets in the expression $(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2$, let $u=x^T\Sigma x$, then we have

$$
(x^T \Sigma x - 1)^2 = (u - 1)^2 = (u - 1)(u - 1) = u^2 - 2u + 1
$$

Again, the expression $u^2 - 2u + 1$ is not DCP, but the expression $u^2 + 2u + 1$ is DCP (note the sign change on the $2u$). Why is this the case and is there a way to resolve it? Thank you

commits.message:
Reformatting the installation page (#2268)

* adding inline tabs for install page

* adding back RDT for build preview

* adding inline tabs to requirements

* adding note for M1 users

* adding card around install instructions

* updating tabs to dropdown for solver installation

* moving test section and removing rtd yaml file

---------

Co-authored-by: Transurgeon <peter.zijie@gmail.com>

pull_request.title: Reformatting the installation page
pull_request.body:
## Description
This PR introduces inline-tabs for cvxpy installation and drop-downs for solver installation instructions.
The updates can be viewed under this [link](https://cvxpy.readthedocs.io/en/inline-tabs/install/index.html).
I believe there was a concern with drop-downs not showing in the search tool, I think this isn't a problem anymore as the information in the dropdown can still be searched.
Issue link (if applicable):

## Type of change

- [ ] New feature (breaking API changes)

- [x] Write unittests.
- [x] Run the unittests and check that they’re passing.
- [x] Run the benchmarks to make sure your change doesn’t introduce a regression.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -483,3 +485,48 @@ def is_dpp(self, context: str = 'dcp') -> bool:
 
     def atoms(self) -> list[Atom]:
         return []
+
+    @property
+    def bounds(self):
+        return self._bounds
+
+    @bounds.setter
+    def bounds(self, value):
+        # In case for a constant or no bounds
+        if value is None:
+            self._bounds = None
+            return
+
+        # Check that bounds is a list of two items
+        if not isinstance(value, list) or len(value) != 2:
+            raise ValueError("Bounds should be a list of two items.")
+
+        lower_bounds, upper_bounds = value
+
+        # Check if lower and upper bounds are always passed together
+        if (lower_bounds is None and upper_bounds is not None):
+            raise ValueError("If upper bounds are passed, lower bounds should also be passed.")
+        if (lower_bounds is not None and upper_bounds is None):
+            raise ValueError("If lower bounds are passed, upper bounds should also be passed.")
+
+        # Check that bounds contains two scalars or two arrays with matching shapes.
+        is_lower_scalar = np.isscalar(lower_bounds)
+        is_upper_scalar = np.isscalar(upper_bounds)
+        is_lower_array = isinstance(lower_bounds, np.ndarray)
+        is_upper_array = isinstance(upper_bounds, np.ndarray)
+        if not((is_lower_scalar and is_upper_scalar) or
+               (is_lower_scalar and is_upper_array
+                and upper_bounds.shape == self.shape) or
+               (is_upper_scalar and is_lower_array
+                and lower_bounds.shape == self.shape) or
+               (is_lower_array and is_upper_array
+                and lower_bounds.shape == self.shape
+                and upper_bounds.shape == self.shape)):
+            raise ValueError("Bounds should contain scalars and/or arrays with the same dimensions")
+
+        # Check that upper_bound >= lower_bound
+        if np.any(upper_bounds < lower_bounds):
comment.body: So if someone provides `[np.inf, np.inf]` as a bound this fails to catch that. We should probably check if there are `np.inf` lower_bounds or `-np.inf` upper bounds and also check for `np.nan` while we're at it...

pull_request.title: Reformatting the installation page
pull_request.body:
## Description
This PR introduces inline-tabs for cvxpy installation and drop-downs for solver installation instructions.
The updates can be viewed under this [link](https://cvxpy.readthedocs.io/en/inline-tabs/install/index.html).
I believe there was a concern with drop-downs not showing in the search tool, I think this isn't a problem anymore as the information in the dropdown can still be searched.
Issue link (if applicable):

## Type of change
- [ ] New feature (backwards compatible)
- [ ] New feature (breaking API changes)
- [ ] Bug fix
- [x] Other (Documentation, CI, ...)

## [Contribution checklist](https://www.cvxpy.org/contributing/index.html#contribution-checklist)
- [x] Add our license to new files.
- [x] Check that your code adheres to our coding style.
- [x] Write unittests.
- [x] Run the unittests and check that they’re passing.
- [x] Run the benchmarks to make sure your change doesn’t introduce a regression.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -139,6 +144,28 @@ def apply(self, problem):
                     constr.append(obj >> 0)
                 elif var.attributes['NSD']:
                     constr.append(obj << 0)
+                elif var.attributes['bounds']:
+                    bounds = var.bounds
+                    lower_bounds, upper_bounds = bounds
+
+                    # Convert scalar bounds to arrays with same shape for uniform handling
+                    if np.isscalar(lower_bounds):
+                        lower_bounds = np.full(obj.shape, lower_bounds)
+                    if np.isscalar(upper_bounds):
+                        upper_bounds = np.full(obj.shape, upper_bounds)
+
+                    # Create masks if -inf or inf is present in the bounds
+                    lower_bound_mask = (lower_bounds != -np.inf)
+                    upper_bound_mask = (upper_bounds != np.inf)
+
+                    # Apply constraints based on the presence of a valid bound
+                    for idx in np.ndindex(obj.shape):
comment.body: Sorry misunderstanding from my side, I replaced the loop by indexing here: [Remove loop for mask](https://github.com/cvxpy/cvxpy/pull/2234/commits/d60e6eed0e96e3ff5a4cda44a89f827fd6e09d73)

pull_request.title: Add support for bounds
pull_request.body:
## Description
The first step of adding the attribute effectively is implementing support for lower and upper bounds for variables and parameters. The second step would involve passing the domain constraints directly to the solver so that solvers can exploit the properties of those types of constraints.
Issue link (if applicable):
https://github.com/cvxpy/cvxpy/issues/1106

## Type of change
- [x] New feature (backwards compatible)
- [ ] New feature (breaking API changes)
- [ ] Bug fix
- [ ] Other (Documentation, CI, ...)

## [Contribution checklist](https://www.cvxpy.org/contributing/index.html#contribution-checklist)
- [ ] Add our license to new files.
- [ ] Check that your code adheres to our coding style.
- [x] Write unittests.
- [x] Run the unittests and check that they’re passing.
- [ ] Run the benchmarks to make sure your change doesn’t introduce a regression.
